title: 113_hr4480
content: The Act is titled the "Protecting Educational Loans for Underserved Students Act." It addresses adverse credit history determinations for Federal Direct PLUS Loan eligibility. Section 455 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include new provisions regarding Federal Direct PLUS Loans. Starting July 1, 2014, the Secretary will assess a student's eligibility for these loans based on their credit history obtained from consumer reporting agencies. Starting July 1, 2014, the Secretary will assess a student's eligibility for Federal Direct PLUS Loans based on their credit history from consumer reporting agencies. An adverse credit history is determined if the student is 90 or more days delinquent on a debt exceeding $2,000 or has had a default determination or bankruptcy discharge in the past 3 years. The Secretary will not consider certain types of debt, such as tax liens or foreclosures, when assessing a student's eligibility for Federal Direct PLUS Loans. Additionally, students with unrelated debt in collections or charged off will not be deemed to have an adverse credit history for loan approval. The Secretary will not consider a student with no credit history as having adverse credit history for Federal Direct PLUS Loan approval. Additionally, students may be required to undergo loan counseling if they have a history of certain actions within a specified timeframe. The Secretary may consider extenuating circumstances for students with adverse credit history, such as medical debt or delinquencies under $2,000. If no adverse credit history is found, the student may qualify for Federal Direct PLUS Loan approval. The Secretary may consider extenuating circumstances for students with adverse credit history, such as medical debt or delinquencies under $2,000, for a 2-year period. The term 'student' refers to a graduate or professional student or the parents of a dependent student. The Higher Education Act of 1965 exempts certain sections from negotiated rulemaking requirements and master calendar exceptions for amendments and regulations.
